dcterms:title: Increased frequency of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential in Bloom syndrome probands and carriers
dcterms:abstract: Bloom syndrome (BSyn, OMIM #210900) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by growth restriction, sun sensitivity, insulin resistance, mild immune deficiency, and increased risk of early-onset malignancy. Using exome sequencing of BSyn patients and BLM carriers, we found that both BSyn probands and BLM carriers exhibited an increased frequency of CHIP compared to sex- and age-matched controls. This study sheds new light on the interplay between genetic predispositions and somatic variation and highlights the need for additional studies to further evaluate the mechanisms and potential clinical implications for patients with one or two BLM PV.

obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:name: hematopoiesis
obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:description: The paper discusses clonal hematopoiesis as a specific form of blood cell production characterized by somatic mutations in leukemia-related genes.

obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:name: clonal hematopoiesis
obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:description: The paper demonstrates that germline variants in DNA repair genes are associated with increased prevalence of clonal hematopoiesis.

obi:RO_0002215.dcterms:description: The study shows that hematopoietic stem cells can undergo clonal expansion, particularly in the context of BLM mutations.

obi:BFO_0000066.dcterms:name: blood cell
obi:BFO_0000066.dcterms:description: The research identifies somatic mutations occurring in blood cells, specifically in leukemia-related genes.

obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:name: DNA repair
obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:description: The paper discusses BLM helicase mutations affecting DNA repair processes, leading to increased genomic instability.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: Bloom syndrome
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by growth restriction, sun sensitivity, insulin resistance, mild immune deficiency, and increased cancer risk. 53% of participants developed cancer, with hematologic malignancies being most common. Study found increased frequency of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) in both Bloom syndrome patients and carriers.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: acute lymphoblastic leukemia
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Identified as one of the cancers occurring in Bloom syndrome patients, with cases reported in the study cohort occurring at ages 4 and 7 years post-collection.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: acute myeloid leukemia
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Reported in one Bloom syndrome patient at age 20 years post-collection.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Occurred in one Bloom syndrome patient at age 20 years post-collection.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: bladder cancer
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Reported in one Bloom syndrome patient at age 6 years post-collection.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: DNA
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: The paper discusses DNA variants and mutations in BLM genes, particularly focusing on how DNA repair mechanisms are affected in Bloom syndrome patients and carriers. The study found increased frequency of somatic DNA variants in CHIP genes in both Bloom syndrome probands and BLM carriers.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: telomere
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: The research indicates that variants in telomere maintenance genes are associated with increased prevalence of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP). This suggests a connection between telomere biology and clonal evolution in hematopoietic cells.
